quoteLast: the _Corsair_ was called and received a message from Brest.
title: The Corsair in the war zone
author: Paine, Ralph Delahaye, 1871-1925

quoteFirst: By the ceasing of the shells on this square it was
quoteLast: o'clock--the hour when the French forces would stream over the top. And for ten minutes, upon the square, the French fire would cease.
title: The Boy Allies with Haig in Flanders; Or, the Fighting Canadians of Vimy Ridge
author: Hayes, Clair W. (Clair Wallace), 1887-

quoteLast: A quarter of the time since noon is 2 hr. 24 min., and a half of the time till noon next day is 7 hr. 12 min. These added together make 9 hr. 36 min.
title: Amusements in Mathematics
author: Dudeney, Henry Ernest, 1857-1930

quoteFirst: It was the third time he had announced this in the last half hour. By his figures the _Flyer_ was over Fogo Island at

quoteFirst: A regular observer in Alabama counted fifteen meteors in one hour’s watching on the evening of July 24, and twenty-one in two hours the following night[V-22]. On the evening of July 26 he apparently took a holiday, but many other persons saw a huge fireball that flashed over North Carolina and Tennessee at
title: The World of Flying Saucers: A Scientific Examination of a Major Myth of the Space Age
author: Menzel, Donald H. (Donald Howard), 1901-1976; Boyd, Lyle Gifford, 1907-1982

quoteFirst: Not only the father of waters, but water himself, scarcely visible at best, “hangs out” all day, rising soon after the sun, and setting as follows: On the 1st, at
quoteLast: ; on the 16th, at 8:40 p. m.; on the 30th, at 7:46 p. m. Has a retrograde motion of 58′ 16″; and on the 16th, at 8:42 p. m., is 2° 13′ north of the moon.
title: The Chautauquan, Vol. 05, April 1885
author: Chautauqua Literary and Scientific Circle; Chautauqua Institution; Flood, Theodore L., 1842- [Editor]
